channel.title: Small app that downloads and gets the client version. (Updated)
channel.description:
Version finder now updates itself, to show how easy and powerful bcel is to directly change classes, and save them. Very useful for bots used in RS to update themselves, you write your code once, let the bot change and write what needs to be updated itself after a RS update!
Its left at the previous RS version, so the first time you run it, it will say RS has been updated, say its saving its updated self, and the current version of RS. The next time you run it, it will just say the version of RS (Until the next time RS updates...)
The downloader can be used to download any file off a url. First parameter is where to save it, and the filename. Second is the url to download from. Defaults to getting runescape.jar if ran with no arugements. bcel.jar and regexp.jar is included, as they are required and not sure how many people would have it. Classes and source is included.
Intended as examples for people that like to look, and be able to figure out what is being done.
Tried to make it simplistic to understand, and used the most basic classes. All heavily commented. All java.
Three classes, as the main program is depenant upon the other two, but the downloader can be ran standalone, and the version finder can be used in a different app, just give it the client class. Up to the user to put in a getter method if they would like to integrate into something else to determine if there has been a update. Just takes one method added that returns the variable...

item.title: Small app that downloads and gets the client version. (Updated)
item.dc:creator: @Nerice Nerice
item.description:
@Nerice wrote:

moparisthebest:

Id venture to say none of us will be around for version 765, a few will be around for 503 though

Well, Wether we are still around at 765 is not the point, if the program would still work is.

I mean if they change thier stuff alot, then its going to break, but at least they have to do something to mess it up.

Read full topic

item.title: Small app that downloads and gets the client version. (Updated)
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

[quote=“NOURLOL, post:8, topic:8964”]503 & 765 aern’t special client versions, but the method where the client version is pushed from the constantpool contains also pushes the values 503,765, the client height & width.

So when either version comes around, there will be either 2x503 pushes, or 2x765 pushes.[/quote]Ahh, lmao. I had no idea.

Read full topic

item.title: Small app that downloads and gets the client version. (Updated)
item.dc:creator: @Nerice Nerice
item.description:
@Nerice wrote:

Nah, I never got them all. Now it has the current/previous known version, looks for it, if its not found, it increases to the next version until it finds it. If its a version after what it knows about, it updates its own class to reflect the new version so the next time its ran, it starts at the latest version it knew about.

Read full topic

item.source: Small app that downloads and gets the client version. (Updated)

item.title: Small app that downloads and gets the client version. (Updated)
item.dc:creator: @Nerice Nerice
item.description:
@Nerice wrote:

Well what I posted is if its 503 || 765 || < 422 || > 800 it breaks, to get the next instruction that was found from the iterator

I have already changed it, just not posted. It keeps the current known version, checks for it, if it fails, then it increases the versoin to check for the next one, and recursively calls itsleft.

If the version increases from what is known, it it changes the method for its own class, so the sipush instruction initilizing the knownVersion variable is set to the current version, and saves the class back to disk. So its set to the current version is changed again by jagex.

Less breakable, and the 503, 765 versions wont matter, and the extra useless parameter would have to be the previous versoin it knows about to break it. Othrwise it wont be affected and correctly id the version.

No idea why they would bother breaking something getting the version number on purpose, but assume the worst.

What I do myself, I look for a change in what it should be, if it is, update to whatever it changed to, version doesnt matter.

Read full topic
item.source: Small app that downloads and gets the client version. (Updated)

item.title: Small app that downloads and gets the client version. (Updated)
item.dc:creator: @NOURLOL NOURLOL
item.description:
@NOURLOL wrote:

[quote=“Nerice, post:3, topic:8964”]Well, as I said, its simplistic, and not advanced, so you might learn something, but it wont be alot. Sort of like a baby step… In fact even in one of the comments you will see I say its a bad way to determine, and why. One reason was to do it fast, and the other reason, was to point out that even though something seems like it might make sense to do, its not. Granted we are only at version 422, but in 81 more versions, it IS broke for that version. No doubt its fubored for 503, 765 version, I will fix it before then to deal with them, but still…

In future versions it will get more advanced, like it will have a variable that sets the current version as the initializer, and if the version changes, change the version initializer, and save it back to disk as a class for the next use etc… Never having to recompile the new class and so forth. In effect, read its own class from disk, change the class, and save it back.[/quote]There really shouldn’t be any pushes apart from 503,765, and the client version, and if you get rid of everything <420 that should leave you with 1 value, assuming you only read SIPUSH instructions. Also, if you arraylist it as I do here (http://www.moparisthebest.com/smf/index.php/topic,11564.0.html) , you will be able to have duplicate 503,765 values, one of which you may remove.

Read full topic

item.title: Small app that downloads and gets the client version. (Updated)
item.dc:creator: @Nerice Nerice
item.description:
@Nerice wrote:

Well, as I said, its simplistic, and not advanced, so you might learn something, but it wont be alot. Sort of like a baby step… In fact even in one of the comments you will see I say its a bad way to determine, and why. One reason was to do it fast, and the other reason, was to point out that even though something seems like it might make sense to do, its not. Granted we are only at version 422, but in 81 more versions, it IS broke for that version. No doubt its fubored for 503, 765 version, I will fix it before then to deal with them, but still…

In future versions it will get more advanced, like it will have a variable that sets the current version as the initializer, and if the version changes, change the version initializer, and save it back to disk as a class for the next use etc… Never having to recompile the new class and so forth. In effect, read its own class from disk, change the class, and save it back.

Read full topic
